reciter.name: Saad Al-Ghamidi
reciter.description: Saad Al-Ghamidi is a renowned Saudi Quran reciter known for his clear and melodious voice. He served as the Imam of the Grand Mosque in Makkah and is respected for his beautiful recitation style.

surahs.description: Al-Fatiha, also known as 'The Opening,' is the first chapter of the Quran. It is recited in every unit of the Muslim prayer (Salah).
Al-Baqarah is the longest surah in the Quran and covers a wide range of topics, including guidance for personal development, society, and law.
Aal-E-Imran covers themes of faith, perseverance, and the importance of family and unity in Islam.
An-Nisa addresses the rights and duties of women, inheritance laws, and the principles of justice and fairness in society.
Al-Ma'idah discusses matters of food, dietary restrictions, punishment for crime, and the relationship between different communities.
Al-An'am emphasizes the importance of following the guidance of Allah, refuting idol worship, and highlighting the consequences of disobedience.
Al-A'raf addresses the story of the prophets, the consequences of disbelief, and the reward for the faithful.
Al-Anfal is centered around the rules of warfare, the ethics of spoils of war, and the importance of loyalty to the community.
At-Tawbah discusses repentance, forgiveness, and the importance of sincerity in turning to Allah after sin.
Surah Yunus focuses on the stories of the prophets, particularly Prophet Yunus, and the challenges they faced in delivering their message.
Surah Hud narrates the stories of various prophets, emphasizing the consequences of disobedience and the rewards of faith.
Surah Yusuf tells the story of Prophet Yusuf (Joseph), highlighting themes of patience, trust in Allah, and the triumph of good over evil.
Ar-Ra'd discusses the power of Allah through natural phenomena like thunder, and emphasizes the truth of the Quranic message.
Surah Ibrahim contains the supplications of Prophet Ibrahim and discusses the consequences of disbelief.
Al-Hijr warns against rejecting the truth and tells the story of the people of Thamud who were destroyed for their disobedience.
An-Nahl discusses the blessings of Allah, including the miracle of honey bees, and calls people to recognize Allah's signs in creation.
Al-Isra discusses the Night Journey of Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) and contains important moral teachings and commandments.
Al-Kahf contains the story of the People of the Cave and provides protection from the trial of the Dajjal (Antichrist).
Surah Maryam tells the story of the miraculous birth of Prophet Isa (Jesus) to Virgin Mary and other prophets.
Ta-Ha contains the story of Prophet Musa (Moses) and provides comfort and reassurance to Prophet Muhammad (PBUH).
Al-Anbiya discusses the stories of various prophets and emphasizes the oneness of Allah and the truth of resurrection.
Al-Hajj discusses the rites of pilgrimage and the importance of devotion to Allah.
Al-Mu'minun describes the qualities of true believers and the consequences of rejecting faith.
An-Nur contains important teachings about modesty, chastity, and the importance of following Allah's light.
Al-Furqan discusses the Quran as the criterion between truth and falsehood, and answers objections of disbelievers.
Ash-Shu'ara tells stories of previous prophets and how their people rejected them, drawing lessons for contemporary listeners.
An-Naml contains the story of Prophet Sulaiman (Solomon) and the queen of Sheba, emphasizing Allah's power and wisdom.
Al-Qasas narrates the story of Prophet Musa (Moses) in detail, showing Allah's plan in human affairs.
Al-Ankabut discusses the tests of faith that believers undergo, comparing false beliefs to a spider's fragile web.
Ar-Rum discusses the victory of the Romans over the Persians as a sign of Allah's power and contains reflections on creation.
Surah Luqman contains the wise advice of Luqman to his son, emphasizing proper worship and good character.
As-Sajda emphasizes the importance of prostration to Allah and discusses creation, resurrection, and divine wisdom.
Al-Ahzab discusses the Battle of the Trench and contains important teachings about family relations and the status of the Prophet's wives.
Saba tells the story of the people of Sheba and their downfall due to ingratitude, warning against arrogance and disbelief.
Fatir discusses Allah's creative power and the contrast between believers and disbelievers in their response to Allah's signs.
Ya-Sin is considered the 'heart of the Quran' and discusses resurrection, the truth of the Quran, and the consequences of disbelief.
As-Saffat discusses the angels who stand in ranks, the unity of Allah, and stories of previous prophets.
Sad discusses the stories of Prophet Dawud (David) and others, warning against arrogance and showing the consequences of rejecting truth.
Az-Zumar emphasizes the oneness of Allah and the importance of sincere worship, contrasting the fate of believers and disbelievers.
Ghafir discusses Allah's forgiveness and contains the story of the believer from Pharaoh's people who kept his faith secret.
Fussilat describes the Quran as a book with clear explanations and warns against rejecting its message.
Ash-Shura discusses the importance of consultation in affairs and contains teachings about divine wisdom and mercy.
Az-Zukhruf refutes the arguments of disbelievers and discusses the temporary nature of worldly luxuries compared to eternal rewards.
Ad-Dukhan warns of a coming punishment in the form of smoke and discusses the fate of previous nations who rejected their prophets.
Al-Jathiya discusses how all people will eventually kneel before Allah and be judged for their deeds.
Al-Ahqaf tells the story of the people of 'Ad who lived among sand dunes and were destroyed for rejecting their prophet.
Surah Muhammad discusses the importance of fighting in Allah's cause and the rewards for those who support His religion.
Al-Fath discusses the Treaty of Hudaybiyyah and the eventual victory it would bring to the Muslims.
Al-Hujurat contains important teachings about proper behavior with the Prophet (PBUH) and among Muslims generally.
Qaf discusses the reality of resurrection and the recording of human deeds, emphasizing the truth of the Quranic message.
Adh-Dhariyat discusses how winds scatter things, just as Allah's promise will scatter the plans of disbelievers.
At-Tur refers to Mount Sinai where Allah spoke to Musa (Moses) and warns of coming punishment for those who reject the truth.
An-Najm describes the Prophet's (PBUH) ascension to the heavens and refutes claims that he speaks from his own desires.
Al-Qamar refers to the splitting of the moon as a sign and warns of coming punishment for those who reject warnings.
Ar-Rahman describes Allah's countless blessings and favors upon humanity and the jinn, repeatedly asking 'Which of your Lord's favors will you deny?'
Al-Waqi'a describes the Day of Judgment and the three groups of people on that day: the foremost, the companions of the right, and the companions of the left.
Al-Hadid discusses the importance of spending in Allah's cause and contains teachings about the temporary nature of worldly life.
Al-Mujadila addresses the case of a woman who pleaded with the Prophet (PBUH) about her husband's unjust treatment, and contains rulings about proper marital relations.
Al-Hashr discusses the exile of the Jewish tribe of Banu Nadir from Medina and contains important teachings about proper distribution of war spoils.
Al-Mumtahana discusses the proper relationship between Muslims and non-Muslims, particularly in matters of loyalty and alliance.
As-Saff criticizes those who say but don't act, and encourages Muslims to stand firmly united in ranks for Allah's cause.
Al-Jumu'a discusses the importance of Friday prayer and criticizes those who prioritize business over remembrance of Allah.
Al-Munafiqun exposes the characteristics of hypocrites and warns against their deceptive behavior.
At-Taghabun discusses how people will realize their mistakes on Judgment Day and warns against being deceived by worldly life.
At-Talaq contains important rulings about divorce and the waiting period ('iddah) for women.
At-Tahrim discusses a personal matter of the Prophet (PBUH) and contains warnings against prohibiting what Allah has made lawful.
Al-Mulk emphasizes Allah's complete control over creation and warns of the punishment in the Hereafter for those who reject the truth.
Al-Qalam defends the character of Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) and contains the parable of the owners of the garden who were punished for their greed.
Al-Haqqah describes the Day of Judgment as an undeniable reality and warns of its terrible punishment for disbelievers.
Al-Ma'arij describes the angels ascending to Allah and discusses human impatience when facing difficulties.
Surah Nuh recounts the story of Prophet Noah and his prolonged efforts to guide his people, who persistently rejected his message.
Al-Jinn contains the testimony of some jinn who accepted Islam after hearing the Quran, acknowledging its truth and power.
Al-Muzzammil contains early commands to the Prophet (PBUH) to stand in prayer at night and be patient with the disbelievers' rejection.
Al-Muddathir contains early commands to the Prophet (PBUH) to arise and warn people, with warnings about Hell for those who reject the message.
Al-Qiyamah discusses the reality of resurrection and how every person will be confronted with their deeds on Judgment Day.
Al-Insan describes the rewards of the righteous in Paradise and discusses human creation and free will.
Al-Mursalat describes winds as Allah's emissaries and warns of the coming Day of Judgment when all deeds will be recompensed.
An-Naba discusses the great news of resurrection and describes scenes from the Day of Judgment.
An-Nazi'at describes angels who take souls at death and contains the story of Musa (Moses) and Pharaoh as a lesson.
Abasa recounts an incident when the Prophet (PBUH) frowned at a blind man who interrupted his conversation with Makkan leaders, teaching the importance of not neglecting anyone seeking knowledge.
At-Takwir describes cosmic disturbances that will occur on Judgment Day and affirms the truth of the Quranic revelation.
Al-Infitar describes the sky splitting apart on Judgment Day and how every soul will see its recorded deeds.
Al-Mutaffifin condemns those who give less than due measure and weight, contrasting their fate with that of the righteous.
Al-Inshiqaq describes the sky splitting and earth casting out its contents on Judgment Day, when people will receive their records of deeds.
Al-Buruj tells the story of faithful people who were burned in trenches for their belief, showing Allah's protection of believers.
At-Tariq describes the piercing star as a sign of Allah's power and emphasizes that every soul has a guardian recording its deeds.
Al-A'la praises Allah as the Most High who creates and proportions everything, and gives success to those who purify themselves.
Al-Ghashiyah describes the overwhelming Day of Judgment and calls people to reflect on Allah's signs in creation.
Al-Fajr warns those who are unjust to others and love wealth excessively, citing examples of destroyed nations like 'Ad and Thamud.
Al-Balad refers to Makkah and discusses the difficult path to righteousness that requires patience, charity, and freeing slaves.
Ash-Shams swears by celestial bodies and the human soul, contrasting the outcomes of those who purify themselves versus those who corrupt themselves.
Al-Layl contrasts those who give charity and seek Allah's pleasure with those who are stingy and deny the truth.
Ad-Duha comforts the Prophet (PBUH) during a period when revelation paused, reminding him of Allah's constant care and blessings.
Ash-Sharh reminds the Prophet (PBUH) that with every difficulty comes ease, and encourages him to turn to worship when free from duties.
At-Tin swears by the fig and olive (symbolic places) and describes how Allah created humans in the best form, though they can fall to the lowest except those with faith.
Al-Alaq contains the first verses revealed to Prophet Muhammad (PBUH), commanding him to read in the name of his Lord who created humans from a clot.
Al-Qadr describes the Night of Decree (Laylat al-Qadr) which is better than a thousand months, when angels descend with Allah's decrees.
Al-Bayyinah discusses how people of previous scriptures divided after clear proofs came to them, and describes the best of creatures as those who believe and do righteous deeds.
Az-Zalzalah describes the earthquake of Judgment Day when earth will disclose its burdens, and every atom's weight of good or evil will be seen.
Al-Adiyat describes charging warhorses as a sign of human ingratitude, as people are often extreme in their love of wealth and neglect of the Hereafter.
Al-Qari'a describes the striking calamity of Judgment Day when people will be like scattered moths and mountains like wool.
At-Takathur criticizes the preoccupation with accumulating wealth and worldly competition that distracts from preparation for the Hereafter.
Al-Asr declares that all humanity is in loss except those who believe, do righteous deeds, advise one another to truth, and advise one another to patience.
Al-Humaza warns of severe punishment for those who slander others and amass wealth thinking it will make them immortal.
Al-Fil recounts how Allah destroyed the army of Abraha that came with elephants to destroy the Kaaba in Makkah.
Quraysh reminds the tribe of the Prophet (PBUH) of Allah's favors in granting them security and sustenance through their trade journeys.
Al-Ma'un criticizes those who pray but are heedless of their prayers, and who refuse small kindnesses to others.
Al-Kawthar gives glad tidings to the Prophet (PBUH) of abundant good, and commands him to pray and sacrifice to his Lord alone.
Al-Kafirun declares the absolute distinction between Islamic monotheism and pagan polytheism, establishing that there can be no compromise in matters of faith.
An-Nasr predicts the coming victory of Islam and commands increased glorification and seeking of Allah's forgiveness when it occurs.
Al-Masad condemns Abu Lahab, an uncle of the Prophet (PBUH) who strongly opposed Islam, and his wife who carried thorns to place in the Prophet's path.
Al-Ikhlas is a pure declaration of Allah's oneness and uniqueness, describing Him as the Eternal Refuge who neither begets nor was begotten.
Al-Falaq seeks refuge in Allah from the evil of what He has created, from darkness when it spreads, and from those who practice witchcraft.
An-Nas seeks refuge in Allah from the whisperings of Satan, whether from jinn or humans, affirming Allah as the true King and God of mankind.
